title: Apartment construction pick-up unclear amid decline in housing starts
text:
Separate UDIA data published last month also predicted a decline in completed dwellings to 46,581 from 58,978 a year earlier. But while a shortfall is inevitable, it is unclear how quick any pick-up in off-the-plan sales and a return to construction will be.

"That’s probably going to be the biggest test of the market," Mr Lawless said.

"Once developers take a position for new projects is when we get a demonstration of buyer demand to be buying off-plan."

Surging clearance rates and a lack of stock for buyers – benefiting from banks' renewed appetite to lend – will push prices high enough to encourage developers to dust off plans and take new projects to market.

But the price pick-up of the past few months hasn't been long enough to prompt a change. Even once people start committing to off-the-plan purchases again, development won't begin immediately.

"It’s going to be a little while," said UDIA Victoria executive director Danni Hunter.

"Because it takes about 18 months from purchase to settlement, even if they’re starting in great numbers now buying off the plan, there would still be a gap in the supply that’s coming in about 18 months."

Confidence in the new apartment market has also been hit by the slew of construction problems, be they combustible cladding or defects, that are devaluing new units and creating unresolved issues of liability and cost.

Ms Hunter said the issues of problem apartments affected existing dwellings and were separate from the pipeline of new homes.
description: While an undersupply is inevitable, the time it will take for off-the-plan units to recover is less certain.
